title: Horse euthanised after allegedly being terrorised by drunken pair
text:
Horse euthanised after allegedly being terrorised by drunken pair MADDISON NORTHCOTT Last updated 18:27, February 23 2017 SUPPLIED 
Gus was a quiet, gentle horse and loved when passersby fed him apples at the fence. 
A Christchurch family are mourning the loss of a horse they loved as a family member after two drunken men allegedly terrorised him. 
Horse owner Karina Romeyn said the pair climbed into her paddock in Burwood and chased the three horses – Gus, Charlie and Steve – during an early morning rampage on Saturday. The duo allegedly hounded Gus through the paddock and left beer bottles strewn in the grass. 
Claudia Anstice, who owned the other two horses, said Gus had been "harassed so much that he was in a blind panic and ran straight into a gate at full force". SUPPLIED 
Police were forced to euthanise Karina Romeyn's horse, Gus, after he was allegedly terrorised by two drunk men early on Saturday morning. 
"There was no sign in the dirt of him slowing down, and even when he hit the gate he seemed to keep going, he must of been terrified," she said. Track marks indicated he had looped around and charged back into a fence before collapsing near the road. 
READ MORE: 
The 7-year-old horse sustained critical injuries, including broken ribs, a punctured lung and internal bleeding. Police were forced to euthanise him by gunshot soon after. SUPPLIED 
Police were forced to euthanise Karina Romeyn's horse, Gus, left, after he was allegedly terrorised by two drunk men early on Saturday morning. 
Anstice said she had no idea how long Gus was left lying in the paddock before the family were alerted by a member of the public. They were trying to piece together his final moments by following the trail of blood spread across the three paddocks on Lake Terrace Rd. 
Charlie and Steve suffered cuts and knocks to their bodies and were traumatised from the incident, she said. 
The now timid pair had been moved to another paddock and "won't leave each other's side". GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Monet Romeyn and Claudia Anstice's horses were abused on Saturday morning, resulting in one of the horses being put down. 
"We're so shocked, angry and sad, it's just hard being here," Anstice said. Ad Feedback 
"It's like a murder scene." 
Monet Romeyn said her mother had owned Gus for about a year, and he had been the perfect animal to help her regain confidence after a riding accident. 
"He was lazy and quiet, and always after food", she said. 
"He used to stand all day at the fence and parents would bring their kids down and feed him apples – he liked that." 
A police spokesperson said officers were "following up lines of inquiries", but no arrests had been made. 
Anyone with information about the incident or who was in the area of Lake Terrace Rd about 4.45am on Saturday was asked to call Christchurch police on 03 363 7400. Information could also be provided anonymously by calling Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111. - Stuff
